It completely changed my energy levels. It made me exothermic again. It made me excited again. It made me want to recommit year after year to Shopify and to Toby and to this mission that we're on.

Go a little deeper on your father and how that's impacted you and what that relationship was like. At 17 years old, the rug got pulled from me, and I was forced to basically grow up overnight. I want to start with what areas of your life do you think you have what other people would consider unreasonably high standards?

Um, maybe start with, I mean, professionally, I think I am... I'm pretty hard on myself in terms of achievement. Um, years ago, I read something about the concept of abundance versus scarcity mindsets. And I think generally, I do not have an abundance mindset about the things in my life. Some of that may be... I don't know, this is going deep as in the first minute, but some of that might just be like multigenerational trauma, which I actually believe in. I think I carry some of the weight of my grandparents, Holocaust survivors, the weight of my father who struggled his whole life financially. But I think the way it manifests most is probably with my own career, that I don't... I still don't think I'm doing enough, that I have enough, that I am enough. And um, that's probably the largest area where I think I have very high standards. Maybe the second one is just I have very high standards for relationships. Go a little deeper on your father and how that's impacted you and what that relationship was like.

My dad is an immigrant. We're sitting here in Montreal. He immigrated here in the 50s. His parents were Holocaust survivors. After the Holocaust, they were in the concentration camps. They survived. They went to Hungary, uh, to a town called Debritton. And during the Hungarian Revolution, things got really bad for everyone, but especially for Jews. Canada had had this amazing program where they let 40,000 Hungarian immigrants come to Canada in the revolution. So actually in Canada, if you meet Hungarians, generally they came in '56 because this sort of cohort of Hungarians came in the 50s. They all came by boat. And um, my dad, when they got here, they didn't have any money. They had no, uh, didn't know anyone here. They certainly didn't have any education. So my grandfather ended up selling eggs at a local farmers market not too far from here called the Jeala farmers market. And he created this egg stand. He called it Lapien. It still stands there today. My uncle runs it. It's been around for, I don't know, 75 years, something like that. And um, I think my dad was always very ambitious. He was... he had that sort of that immigrant ambition. He wanted to... he wanted to have a better life than his parents had, and he wanted his children to have a better life than he had. And growing up, he always sort of made us feel like we had... we had enough. There was never sort of a sense of scarcity, uh, in the house whatsoever. It was only later in life that I realized that that it was a bit of a fugazi. It was... it was fake. Uh, that we really didn't have very much. But at the time, I didn't know that. It felt like I had enough. And um, where things came to a head and and and you know, you and I have been friends for a long time, so you know the story. Um, was when I was 17, my dad was arrested. I went to prison, and that was sort of the first time that I saw true vulnerability. That's that's where it all sort of the facade of a secure foundation came crumbling down for me. I remember we moved to South Florida in 1996 or '95 or so. I was around 12 years old. The area we moved into, it was in Boca Raton, Florida in Palm Beach County. Boca is well known as being a fairly wealthy area, but we were not wealthy. I mean, again, when we lived in Montreal, I didn't experience any... there was always food on my table. I always felt like, you know, I didn't always have all the stuff that I wanted, the, you know, the Air Jordans, but I had one pair of Air Jordans. Um, and so I didn't... I didn't live a life of where I didn't have enough growing up. But I remember moving to South Florida, and that was the first time I think that I realized that other people have a lot more than I did. There were gated communities everywhere, but we didn't live in one. There were incredible private schools everywhere, but I couldn't attend one because it was too expensive. It was sort of in that age group, in that sort of range where I began to realize that um, my father wanted to have a better life than he did. That he was... he wasn't living in a community where we were the average or we were above average. We were living in a community where we were below average. I remember asking my parents why I couldn't go to private school. There were these beautiful private schools all over Boca Raton, these with these big, beautiful gates and these wonderful buildings. And I remember asking my parents, "Why can't I go to Pinerest or St. Andrews," which are the two big schools? And my mom said, "We can't afford it." It was like $30,000 a year, which was an insane amount of money for my parents at that point. And I think that's actually around when I began to get my first chip on my shoulder. Something didn't sit fully well with me. And and I... I think the way it manifested was ambition, competitiveness, some insecurity. So, I mean, there I was going to a public high school in South Florida. I was a, you know, I was a short Jewish kid from Montreal, Canada. Moved to South Florida. Had no friends or family. There were 4,000 students at the school. And there were students from all different backgrounds. Some live in Boca. Some were being busted in from Del Rey, a much lower lower income community. There were police officers because that's what you had at big American public high schools. And I was scared shitless. I don't know sort of what what drove me then, but like within a year, I was like president of student council. I was wrestling varsity, uh, because I figured out actually one of the advantages of being short and kind of stocky was I was a pretty good wrestler. And so I was able to change my circumstances by sheer will at that point. The second thing that happened around that same period of time was that I really... I was 13, and as as as you've heard before, you heard me talk about, all 13-year-old Jewish kids go to a lot of bar mitzvahs almost every weekend. Um, and I was enamored by DJs. I thought these DJs at these bar mitzvahs were like magicians. And I really thought these were the coolest people I'd ever seen. And although my dad didn't have a lot of money, the one thing he... he did do, and he's done this my whole life, was anytime I... I had an idea, and I shared with my father, he would say, "Great idea." He actually... there would be a physical manifestation of that, which was that he would make me these business cards. And uh, um, tonight you and I are having dinner at my home, and we'll go to my off my home office, and I would show you those early business cards, but I still have them lined up in my office. Every time I had a silly idea about a business, my father would come home with a business card that said my name and the business name. And it was this very simple physical device that was the equivalent of him saying, "You absolutely can do this. You are... you you have the capacity. You have the willpower. You are... you have the entitlement. Like you are... you can do this. You have the permission to go do this." And I ended up DJing 500 bar mitzvahs after that. Started my own DJ company, hired myself, and that was sort of my relationship with my... I think with my dad over over my life, which is that I don't think I fully understood the baggage he was carrying with him his whole life. But he was unequivocally supportive and loving of me. And even when years later when he... when he went away and we lost all our money, it was tough for me to hate him because ultimately what I really believed was he was doing it for me. That he was going... he was taking massive risks with his own life and his own freedom in order to give me and my two much younger... one of my sisters is 10 years younger, the other is is three years younger. He was doing it to give me and my siblings a much better life. And he was willing to risk what ended up being five or six years of federal prison time to provide that for us. And as I sort of reflect on on my upbringing and my childhood, it'd be difficult for me not to credit his transfer of confidence to me with kind of how I ended up. So I have... I have anxiety now. Uh, I... I am uh, constantly, you know, trying to do more, feel more, build more, have more. That that that that feeling of scarcity is in me. There's a bunch of negative externalities that come with that. But the other thing that came with it is what I believe to be an incredible amount of ambition. And that ambition and that energy, you... you and I have a lot of mutual friends, and and and I... I think most of our mutual friends would describe me as someone that has... is constantly high energy. That high energy mostly comes from a place of deviv and excitement, and you... I heard this great quote that part of being happy is being excited by the elements... all the elements of your life. I'm excited by all the elements of my life, and I think that while I probably have a complicated relationship with my dad, I am here and I have this life partially because of him.

Thank you for sharing.
